riskAssessment.riskLevelDescription: Minor health concerns requiring routine monitoring

predictedCondition.description: Based on observed symptoms and risk factors, the animal shows no significant health concerns. Risk assessment indicates low risk level with 1-3% mortality probability.

monitoringRecommendations.details: Weekly weight measurements and growth rate calculations. Monitor colostrum intake within first 6 hours (4L minimum). Assess navel healing and check for umbilical infections. Monitor feeding behavior, milk intake volume, and starter feed consumption. Check for scours using fecal scoring system and monitor hydration status closely.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Daily health checks, weekly weights, feeding monitoring at each meal
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: Weight gain: 0.5-0.8 kg/day, Normal navel healing, Active nursing behavior
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: Weight loss, swollen navel, diarrhea, dehydration, failure to nurse

monitoringRecommendations.details: Monitor for heat stress indicators including panting (>80 breaths/min), drooling, seeking shade, and reduced feed intake during hot periods. Use Temperature-Humidity Index (THI) calculations to assess heat stress risk. Provide adequate water (increase by 50% during heat waves) and electrolyte supplementation. Monitor core body temperature rectally during peak heat periods.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Every 2 hours during peak heat (10 AM - 6 PM)
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: THI <70 (no stress), Respiratory rate <60/min, Normal water intake
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: THI >80, Panting >80 breaths/min, Rectal temp >105°F, Reduced water intake

monitoringRecommendations.details: Daily visual assessment of general health including alertness, appetite, normal posture, and social behavior. Weekly detailed physical examination including temperature, pulse, respiration. Monthly body condition scoring and weight estimation. Quarterly comprehensive health evaluation including blood work if indicated.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Daily visual, weekly detailed, monthly BCS, quarterly comprehensive
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: Alert and responsive, normal vital signs, appropriate body condition
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: Any deviation from normal behavior, vital sign abnormalities, body condition changes

healthAssessment.seasonalAlert: High heat stress risk. Ensure adequate shade and water. Monitor for signs of heat exhaustion.
climateConsiderations: Increase water intake frequency and quantity
Provide shade and cooling systems
Monitor for dehydration and heat stress
Adjust feeding times to cooler parts of the day
nextStepRecommendations: Continue routine health monitoring and preventive care
Maintain vaccination and deworming schedule
Regular nutritional assessment and body condition scoring

riskAssessment.riskLevelDescription: Significant health risks requiring veterinary evaluation

predictedCondition.condition: Moderate risk - Professional veterinary consultation recommended
predictedCondition.description: Based on observed symptoms and risk factors, the animal shows signs of respiratory infection. Risk assessment indicates moderate risk level with 3-10% mortality probability.

monitoringRecommendations.details: Count respiratory rate for full minute while animal is at rest. Observe for abdominal breathing, nostril flaring, or open-mouth breathing. Listen for abnormal sounds (wheezing, rattling). Check nasal discharge characteristics: color, consistency, odor, and bilateral vs unilateral presentation.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Every 4 hours during symptomatic period
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: Respiratory rate: Adult cattle 26-50 breaths/min, Calves 40-60 breaths/min
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: Rate >60/min in adults, labored breathing, blue-tinged mucous membranes, thick yellow/green discharge

monitoringRecommendations.action: Body Temperature and Respiratory Environment Assessment
monitoringRecommendations.details: Take rectal temperature using digital thermometer, hold for 60 seconds. Monitor ambient temperature, humidity, and air quality in housing area. Check for drafts, dust levels, and ventilation adequacy. Document any correlation between environmental conditions and symptom severity.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Temperature: 3 times daily; Environment: Daily assessment
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: Body temperature: 101.5-103.5°F (38.6-39.7°C)
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: Temperature >104°F or <100°F, high humidity >80%, poor air circulation

monitoringRecommendations.details: Weekly weight measurements and growth rate calculations. Monitor colostrum intake within first 6 hours (4L minimum). Assess navel healing and check for umbilical infections. Monitor feeding behavior, milk intake volume, and starter feed consumption. Check for scours using fecal scoring system and monitor hydration status closely.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Daily health checks, weekly weights, feeding monitoring at each meal
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: Weight gain: 0.5-0.8 kg/day, Normal navel healing, Active nursing behavior
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: Weight loss, swollen navel, diarrhea, dehydration, failure to nurse

monitoringRecommendations.details: Monitor for heat stress indicators including panting (>80 breaths/min), drooling, seeking shade, and reduced feed intake during hot periods. Use Temperature-Humidity Index (THI) calculations to assess heat stress risk. Provide adequate water (increase by 50% during heat waves) and electrolyte supplementation. Monitor core body temperature rectally during peak heat periods.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Every 2 hours during peak heat (10 AM - 6 PM)
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: THI <70 (no stress), Respiratory rate <60/min, Normal water intake
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: THI >80, Panting >80 breaths/min, Rectal temp >105°F, Reduced water intake

healthAssessment.seasonalAlert: High heat stress risk. Ensure adequate shade and water. Monitor for signs of heat exhaustion.
climateConsiderations: Increase water intake frequency and quantity
Provide shade and cooling systems
Monitor for dehydration and heat stress
Adjust feeding times to cooler parts of the day
nextStepRecommendations: Chest auscultation and temperature monitoring
Consider antibiotic treatment if bacterial infection suspected
Improve ventilation and reduce dust exposure

riskAssessment.riskLevelDescription: Significant health risks requiring veterinary evaluation

predictedCondition.condition: Moderate risk - Professional veterinary consultation recommended
predictedCondition.description: Based on observed symptoms and risk factors, the animal shows signs of digestive disorders. Risk assessment indicates moderate risk level with 3-10% mortality probability.

monitoringRecommendations.details: Monitor hydration status every 2-4 hours by checking skin tent test (normal: <2 seconds), mucous membrane color (should be pink), and capillary refill time (<2 seconds). Record water intake volume and frequency. Check for sunken eyes, dry nose, and reduced skin elasticity.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Every 2-4 hours during acute phase, then every 8 hours
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: Water intake: 30-50L/day for adult cattle, Skin tent test: <2 seconds
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: Skin tent >3 seconds, dark urine, decreased urination, sunken eyes, dry mucous membranes

monitoringRecommendations.details: Document fecal consistency using Bristol Stool Scale adaptation for cattle. Record frequency, volume, color, presence of blood, mucus, or undigested feed. Note any changes in odor intensity. Collect samples for laboratory analysis if diarrhea persists >24 hours.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Every defecation event for first 48 hours, then 3 times daily
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: Normal: Semi-solid, brown, 12-18 bowel movements/day
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: Watery consistency, blood presence, foul odor, >20 movements/day, green coloration

monitoringRecommendations.details: Weekly weight measurements and growth rate calculations. Monitor colostrum intake within first 6 hours (4L minimum). Assess navel healing and check for umbilical infections. Monitor feeding behavior, milk intake volume, and starter feed consumption. Check for scours using fecal scoring system and monitor hydration status closely.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Daily health checks, weekly weights, feeding monitoring at each meal
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: Weight gain: 0.5-0.8 kg/day, Normal navel healing, Active nursing behavior
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: Weight loss, swollen navel, diarrhea, dehydration, failure to nurse

monitoringRecommendations.details: Monitor for heat stress indicators including panting (>80 breaths/min), drooling, seeking shade, and reduced feed intake during hot periods. Use Temperature-Humidity Index (THI) calculations to assess heat stress risk. Provide adequate water (increase by 50% during heat waves) and electrolyte supplementation. Monitor core body temperature rectally during peak heat periods.
monitoringRecommendations.frequency: Every 2 hours during peak heat (10 AM - 6 PM)
monitoringRecommendations.normalValues: THI <70 (no stress), Respiratory rate <60/min, Normal water intake
monitoringRecommendations.alertSigns: THI >80, Panting >80 breaths/min, Rectal temp >105°F, Reduced water intake

healthAssessment.seasonalAlert: High heat stress risk. Ensure adequate shade and water. Monitor for signs of heat exhaustion.
climateConsiderations: Increase water intake frequency and quantity
Provide shade and cooling systems
Monitor for dehydration and heat stress
Adjust feeding times to cooler parts of the day
Electrolyte replacement is critical in hot conditions
nextStepRecommendations: Fecal examination for parasites and pathogens
Fluid therapy if dehydration present
Dietary modification and probiotics consideration
